content.h2: Can I tell other people about AMQ?
content.p: If you have to ask this question, the answer is "no".
content.h2: What is the status of the OpenAMQ project?
content.p: Development started in October 2004, and we are currently at a version 0.8 which implements the core of AMQP. We plan to review the AMQP specifications to make the protocol more general, following the seven months of experience from implementing the server and clients. This 0.9 protocol specification is planned for mid-May. The server and clients will conform to that specification by end-May. At the same time we are implementing native multithreading in the server to achieve our target volumes (100k messages/second) on large boxes. The 1.0 release has not been specifically planned but should be ready by October 2005, approximately one year after development of the software started.
content.h2: Will OpenAMQ handle 100k messages per second?
content.p: A lot depends on the type of messages and whether we achieve a good use of OS threads to spread work out between multiple CPUs. The matching engine in OpenAMQ can today perform about 2M matches per second per Ghz. So our bottlenecks will mainly be network i/o, and disk i/o for persistent messages.
It's open source, it's ANSI C, it's fast, and small. The server runs in 3-4MB, depending on the size of in-memory queues.
AMQP - the protocol - defines a wire-level standard, so you can develop your own bridges, clients, and servers that interoperate with or replace the standard components.

The OpenAMQ clients and server implement industrial-quality messaging, capable of running in production scenarios. The software must still be hardened for stress cases. But its goal is simple: to provide an open source commodity middleware that performs at least as well as, and generally better than, any commercially-available middleware product.
content.h2: How can I participate in the OpenAMQ process?
content.p: You should join the amq-dev mailing list
